article.title: Far-from-equilibrium attractors and nonlinear dynamical systems approach to the Gubser flow

multiple_choice_question.text:
Formula (2.5):

∂ρf(ρ, pˆ<sup>2</sup><sub>Ω</sub>, pˆ<sub>ς</sub>) = - 1/τˆ<sub>r</sub>(ρ) ( f(ρ, pˆ<sup>2</sup><sub>Ω</sub>, pˆ<sub>ς</sub>) - f<sub>eq</sub>(-uˆ · pˆ/Tˆ(ρ)) ) 

**Question:** This formula represents:
choices: The anisotropic hydrodynamic equation for Gubser flow.
The Israel-Stewart equation for Gubser flow.
The relaxation time approximation (RTA) Boltzmann equation for Gubser flow.
The Lyapunov equation for Gubser flow.

multiple_choice_question.text:
Formula (2.12):

∂<sub>ρ</sub>Tˆ/Tˆ + 2/3 tanh ρ = π¯/3 tanh ρ 

**Question:** This formula describes:
choices: The evolution of shear stress in Gubser flow.
The evolution of temperature in Gubser flow.
The pressure anisotropy in Gubser flow.
The Lyapunov exponent in Gubser flow.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1:\n\n**Question:** What does Figure 1 illustrate about the Gubser flow in the Israel-Stewart (IS) theory?
choices: The flow lines converge to a single stable fixed point for all initial conditions.
The system exhibits chaotic behavior with no clear attractor.
There are three fixed points: two unstable saddle points and one stable fixed point.
The attractor is a 2-dimensional planar manifold.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2:\n\n**Question:** What does the wedge shape near the fixed point (0, 1/√5) in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The initial conditions leading to divergent flow lines.
The basin of attraction for the stable fixed point.
The chaotic region of the phase space.
The asymptotic behavior of the Gubser attractor at late times.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3:\n\n**Question:** Figure 3 depicts the local basin of attraction for the 3D system (3.22) in the IS theory using a Lyapunov function. What does the red dot at the origin represent?
choices: An unstable saddle point.
The initial condition for all flow lines.
The global basin of attraction.
The stable steady state of the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5:\n\n**Question:** What can be concluded from Figure 5 about the asymptotic attractors of different hydrodynamical models and the exact solution?
choices: All models perfectly match the exact attractor for all initial conditions.
DNMR and IS are in good agreement with the exact attractor at large w.
Anisotropic hydrodynamics (aHydro) reproduces the exact attractor with high accuracy.
The attractors of all models are prolate configurations regardless of initial conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 6:\n\n**Question:** Figure 6 compares the asymptotic attractors of different models with the exact Gubser solution. Which model provides the best quantitative description of the exact attractor?
choices: Israel-Stewart (IS)
DNMR
Anisotropic hydrodynamics (aHydro)
None of the above

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7:\n\n**Question:** What does Figure 7 demonstrate about the asymptotic series expansions of the IS and DNMR theories?
choices: Both series converge for all values of c.
The DNMR series converges faster than the IS series.
Both series are divergent.
The IS series is convergent while the DNMR series is divergent.
